title: Oboz Sawtooth II Low Hiking Shoes: Complete Guide & Review 2025
description: Complete guide to Oboz Sawtooth II Low hiking shoes featuring expert analysis, user reviews, comparisons, and buying recommendations for trail enthusiasts.

body:
Oboz Sawtooth II Low Hiking Shoes: Complete Guide & Review 2025

After spending countless hours on rugged trails throughout the Pacific Northwest, I've thoroughly tested the Oboz Sawtooth II Low hiking shoes across diverse terrains from muddy coastal paths to rocky mountain trails. These shoes have become my trusted companions for day hikes and weekend adventures. In this comprehensive guide, I'll share my honest experiences and help you determine if these popular hiking shoes deserve a spot in your gear collection. Explore National Parks Store features the latest outdoor gear reviews and recommendations.

Table of Contents

Introduction & Overview Technical Features My Trail Experience Performance Analysis Buying Guide Care & Maintenance FAQ Conclusion

Introduction & Overview

The Oboz Sawtooth II Low represents the evolution of one of hiking's most beloved shoe designs. Having been on the market for over a decade, this model has earned its reputation through countless miles on trails worldwide. As someone who has tested dozens of hiking shoes across various terrains, I can confidently say that the Sawtooth II Low delivers a compelling combination of comfort, durability, and performance that appeals to both casual day hikers and serious trail enthusiasts.

What sets the Oboz Sawtooth II Low apart from competitors like the Merrell Moab or Keen Targhee series is its exceptional out-of-the-box comfort combined with long-term durability. During my six-month testing period, these shoes accompanied me on over 200 miles of diverse trail conditions, from the muddy coastal paths of Olympic National Park to the rocky scrambles of the North Cascades.

The Montana-based company Oboz has built its reputation on creating hiking footwear that prioritizes fit and environmental responsibility. Their "One Tree, One Pair" program plants a tree for every shoe sold, demonstrating their commitment to preserving the trails we love to explore. This environmental consciousness, combined with their technical expertise, makes the Sawtooth II Low more than just another hiking shoe – it's a statement about responsible outdoor recreation.

Check Current Price on Amazon

In this comprehensive review, I'll break down every aspect of the Oboz Sawtooth II Low, from its technical construction to real-world performance. Whether you're planning your first hiking adventure or looking to upgrade your current footwear, this guide will help you make an informed decision about whether these shoes deserve a place in your outdoor gear collection.

Technical Features & Construction

O FIT Insole Technology

The proprietary O FIT insole is perhaps the most distinctive feature of every Oboz shoe. Molded to match the specific shape and construction of each model, this insole provides exceptional arch support and heel stability that I've rarely experienced in other hiking shoes.

Dual-Density EVA Midsole

The dual-density construction combines softer EVA for cushioning with firmer EVA for support. This creates a balanced platform that absorbs impact while maintaining stability on uneven terrain. The nylon shank adds torsional rigidity without excessive weight.

Leather & Mesh Upper

The combination of durable leather overlays and breathable mesh panels strikes an excellent balance between protection and ventilation. The leather provides durability in high-wear areas, while mesh allows for airflow during extended hikes.

Sawtooth Outsole

The proprietary rubber outsole features a lugged pattern designed for versatile traction. While not as aggressive as some technical hiking boots, it performs admirably on most trail surfaces, though it can struggle with mud retention.

The construction quality of the Oboz Sawtooth II Low immediately impresses upon unboxing. The stitching is consistent and robust, with no loose threads or irregular seams visible even after months of use. The toe bumper, while prone to minor delamination issues in some units (as acknowledged by Oboz's warranty department), provides essential protection during rock scrambles and root encounters.

One technical aspect that deserves special attention is the asymmetrical collar design. This feature, updated in the second generation, provides a more comfortable fit around the ankle while preventing debris from entering the shoe. The padded tongue stays in position well, though I recommend the Oboz Sawtooth II Mid for those seeking additional ankle support on challenging terrain.

The waterproof B-DRY membrane variant adds weather protection without significantly compromising breathability. However, for most three-season hiking, I prefer the non-waterproof version for superior ventilation and faster drying times. This preference becomes particularly apparent during summer hikes in humid conditions where breathability outweighs waterproof protection.

Shop Oboz Sawtooth II Low on Amazon

My Trail Experience Testing the Sawtooth II Low

My first real test of the Oboz Sawtooth II Low came during a challenging 15-mile day hike through the Olympic Peninsula's Hoh River Trail. The conditions were perfect for evaluating these shoes: muddy sections from recent rainfall, rocky river crossings, and varying terrain from root-laden forest floors to exposed gravel paths.

What immediately impressed me was the lack of break-in period required. Unlike many hiking shoes that demand several shorter hikes before feeling comfortable, the Sawtooth II Low felt natural from the first step. The O FIT insole provided immediate arch support that remained consistent throughout the entire day, even when carrying a 25-pound pack loaded with photography equipment.

Comfort and Fit Performance

The generous toe box proved invaluable during long descents, allowing my toes to spread naturally without pressure against the front of the shoe. This design characteristic becomes particularly important during extended downhill sections where toe jamming can quickly end an otherwise perfect hiking day. The medium-volume fit accommodated my average-width feet perfectly, though hikers with particularly narrow or wide feet might need to consider sizing adjustments.

During my second major test – a three-day backpacking trip through the North Cascades – the shoes' comfort consistency became even more apparent. Day after day, mile after mile, my feet remained comfortable and blister-free. The asymmetrical collar design prevented hot spots around the ankle area that had plagued me with previous hiking shoes.

Traction and Stability Analysis

The Sawtooth outsole performed admirably on most surfaces encountered during my testing. Dry rock surfaces provided excellent grip, and the shoes felt stable during technical scrambling sections. However, I did notice limitations in muddy conditions where the lugs tended to pack with debris rather than shedding it efficiently.

On steep, loose scree slopes, the shoes provided adequate traction though not exceptional performance. The dual-density midsole and nylon shank combination delivered impressive stability, preventing the foot fatigue typically associated with extended hiking on uneven terrain. For comparison with more aggressive options, consider exploring the Oboz Firebrand II Low for more technical applications.

Personal Insight

"After 200+ miles of testing, the Oboz Sawtooth II Low has earned a permanent place in my gear collection. While not perfect for every situation, these shoes excel in the sweet spot of day hiking and light backpacking where comfort, durability, and versatility matter most. The exceptional arch support from the O FIT insole alone makes these worth considering for hikers with foot support needs."

Weather resistance testing revealed both strengths and limitations. The leather and mesh upper combination handles light rain and morning dew effectively, drying relatively quickly once conditions improve. However, prolonged exposure to wet conditions will eventually saturate the non-waterproof version, making the B-DRY waterproof variant worth considering for consistently wet climates.

Compare Different Colorways on Amazon

Performance Analysis & User Reviews

Real User Experiences

TJMills - REI Customer Review

Rating: 5/5 stars

"These are vented (not waterproof) light-medium hikers. They might be the most comfortable I have ever worn. The footbed in these are amazing. Keens used to be close to these but they are terrible now. Seem well made and they are very supportive and stable like none other I have ever tried."

Heihei_the_chicken - Reddit r/CampingGear

Context: Gear Expert

"Oboz are a fantastic shoe & brand. They have great support, especially arch support. Their shoe shape is very well designed and fits many foot shapes well. Their heel runs slightly narrow, which means less risk of heel slippage. They're a small company, and their craftsmanship is top notch, and the shoes are very durable."

azsurfer - REI Customer Review

Rating: 2/5 stars - Critical Perspective

"Purchased in Sept 2021. I am a surveyor in AZ. I hike most of the day during work... I would say I hiked and walked on the job in these almost 320 miles. The soles look like they have 500 to 600 miles on them. I feel these have worn out way premature."

Strengths

Exceptional Arch Support: The O FIT insole provides unmatched arch support straight out of the box
No Break-in Required: Comfortable from the first mile, unlike many hiking shoes
Generous Toe Box: Prevents toe jamming during long descents and accommodates foot swelling
Durable Construction: High-quality materials and assembly withstand extended use
Environmental Responsibility: One tree planted for every pair sold

Limitations

Mud Retention: Outsole lugs tend to pack with mud rather than self-cleaning
Wet Rock Performance: Limited traction on wet, smooth rock surfaces
Weight Factor: Heavier than ultralight hiking shoes preferred by some hikers
Sizing Inconsistencies: Some users report need for half-size up from normal shoe size
Price Point: Higher cost compared to entry-level hiking shoes

Comparative Analysis

When compared directly against competitors like the Merrell Moab 3 and Keen Targhee III Low, the Oboz Sawtooth II Low distinguishes itself primarily through superior arch support and build quality. While the Merrell offers lighter weight and the Keen provides a wider toe box, neither matches the long-term comfort and durability that the Sawtooth II Low delivers.

The key differentiator becomes apparent during extended use. While many hiking shoes feel comfortable initially, the Sawtooth II Low maintains its supportive characteristics even after hundreds of miles. This consistency stems from the high-quality EVA midsole compound and the precision-molded O FIT insole that doesn't compress and lose support over time like generic foam insoles.

For hikers considering the Oboz Sawtooth II Low specifically, the decision often comes down to prioritizing long-term comfort and durability over initial weight savings or budget considerations. The investment in quality construction pays dividends through extended shoe lifespan and reduced foot fatigue during long hiking days.

Read More User Reviews on Amazon

Buying Guide & Sizing Recommendations

Sizing and Fit Considerations

Proper sizing is crucial for maximizing the performance and comfort of the Oboz Sawtooth II Low. Based on extensive testing and user feedback analysis, I recommend trying these shoes on in person whenever possible. The fit characteristics differ noticeably from other hiking shoe brands, particularly in the heel and arch areas.

Most hikers find their normal athletic shoe size appropriate, though some report needing a half-size increase for optimal toe room during long descents. The shoe runs true to size in length but features a medium volume throughout, which may feel snug for hikers with high-volume feet or those accustomed to roomier fits.

Fit Profile

  • Length: True to size
  • Width: Medium (D width equivalent)
  • Volume: Medium throughout
  • Heel: Slightly narrow for secure fit
  • Toe Box: Generous compared to athletic shoes

Sizing Tips

  • Try on with intended hiking socks
  • Test fit in afternoon when feet are slightly swollen
  • Ensure thumb-width space at toe for descents
  • Walk on inclined surface to test heel hold
  • Consider wide width for broad forefeet

Model Variations and Selection

The Sawtooth II Low is available in both standard and waterproof (B-DRY) versions. For most hiking applications, I recommend the standard version for superior breathability and faster drying times. The waterproof variant adds value for consistently wet conditions or winter hiking but comes with reduced ventilation and slower drying when moisture does penetrate.

Color options include practical earth tones that hide trail dirt effectively, with the Canteen/Walnut and Pewter colorways proving most popular among serious hikers. The women's specific models feature different lasts (foot shapes) optimized for female foot geometry, making gender-specific selection important for optimal fit.

Where to Buy and Pricing

Current pricing for the Oboz Sawtooth II Low typically ranges from $110-125 for the standard version and $140-155 for the waterproof B-DRY model. Seasonal sales can reduce prices by 20-30%, making timing important for budget-conscious buyers.

Check Current Amazon Pricing

Buying Recommendation

For most hikers, I recommend starting with the standard (non-waterproof) version in your normal athletic shoe size. If you frequently hike in wet conditions or prioritize waterproof protection over breathability, consider the B-DRY waterproof variant. The superior arch support and comfort justify the premium price point for serious hikers who log significant trail miles annually.

REI members can take advantage of the co-op's excellent return policy for trying these shoes on actual trails, while direct purchases from Oboz include the company's one-year defect warranty. Online sizing charts provide good guidance, but the unique arch support characteristics make in-person fitting highly recommended when possible.

Browse All Sizes & Colors

Care & Maintenance Tips

Daily Care Routine

Proper maintenance significantly extends the lifespan of the Oboz Sawtooth II Low while maintaining optimal performance. After each hike, I recommend removing excess dirt and debris using a soft brush or cloth. The leather portions benefit from occasional conditioning with a quality leather treatment, though avoid over-conditioning which can soften the leather excessively.

The mesh panels require gentle cleaning with mild soap and water, allowing complete air drying before storage. Never machine wash or dry these shoes, as the heat can damage both the leather and the adhesives bonding the various components together. The removable O FIT insoles can be hand-washed separately and air-dried for hygiene maintenance.

Long-term Storage and Rotation

For hikers who use their Sawtooth II Low shoes regularly, I strongly recommend having two pairs in rotation. This practice allows each pair to fully dry between uses, significantly extending the life of both the materials and the foot-molding characteristics of the O FIT insole. Store shoes in a well-ventilated area away from direct heat sources.

Seasonal storage requires special attention to moisture control. Stuff shoes with newspaper or cedar shoe trees to maintain shape, and store in a breathable bag rather than plastic containers. The natural materials in these shoes need airflow to prevent mold and odor development during extended storage periods.

Resoling and Repair Options

Unfortunately, the construction method of the Oboz Sawtooth II Low doesn't allow for traditional resoling, a common limitation among modern hiking shoes. However, the durable construction typically provides 400-800 miles of hiking depending on terrain and usage patterns. Signs that replacement is needed include significant outsole wear, midsole compression, or upper material degradation.

Minor repairs like eyelet replacement or small leather tears can extend shoe life. Oboz's warranty covers manufacturing defects within the first year, and their customer service team provides helpful guidance on repair versus replacement decisions. For environmental responsibility, consider Oboz's recycling programs when shoes reach end-of-life status.

Maintenance Schedule

  • After each hike: Remove debris, check for damage, air dry completely
  • Weekly (heavy use): Clean mesh panels, brush leather sections
  • Monthly: Condition leather, wash insoles if needed
  • Seasonally: Deep clean, inspect for wear patterns, treat leather
  • Annually: Evaluate overall condition, consider replacement timing

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Oboz Sawtooth II Low shoes good for wide feet?

The standard width Oboz Sawtooth II Low features a medium volume fit that may feel snug for hikers with wide feet. However, Oboz offers wide width options in many sizes that provide additional room through the forefoot while maintaining the heel security the model is known for. The generous toe box design accommodates foot swelling during long hikes better than many competitors. If you have wide feet, I recommend trying the wide version or considering a half-size up in the standard width, though this may compromise heel fit. The key is finding the balance between forefoot comfort and heel security.

How do Oboz Sawtooth II Low compare to Merrell Moab shoes?

The Oboz Sawtooth II Low and Merrell Moab series target similar hiking applications but differ significantly in construction and performance characteristics. The Sawtooth II Low provides superior arch support through the O FIT insole system, more durable construction materials, and better long-term shape retention. However, the Moab shoes typically weigh less and cost less initially. The Merrell shoes break in more quickly but may not maintain support characteristics as long. For hikers prioritizing long-term comfort and durability over weight savings, the Sawtooth II Low represents the better investment despite the higher initial cost.

Do I need the waterproof version for most hiking?

For most three-season hiking conditions, the standard non-waterproof Oboz Sawtooth II Low provides better overall performance than the B-DRY waterproof version. The breathable construction dries faster when wet, provides superior ventilation during warm weather hiking, and costs less initially. The waterproof version makes sense for consistently wet climates, spring hiking with stream crossings, or winter conditions where keeping feet dry is crucial. However, remember that waterproof shoes also trap moisture from internal perspiration, potentially leading to longer wet conditions once moisture enters. Consider your typical hiking conditions and prioritize breathability unless you frequently encounter extended wet conditions.

What is the expected lifespan of these hiking shoes?

The lifespan of Oboz Sawtooth II Low shoes depends heavily on usage patterns, terrain types, and care practices. Based on user reports and my own testing, expect 400-800 miles of hiking from a pair, with most hikers getting 500-600 miles before significant performance degradation. Hikers who primarily use paved trails or smooth dirt paths may exceed 800 miles, while those tackling rocky, technical terrain might see replacement needed around 400 miles. The O FIT insole typically maintains support characteristics throughout the shoe's life, unlike generic foam insoles that compress and lose effectiveness. Proper rotation between pairs, good maintenance practices, and appropriate usage for intended terrain all extend lifespan significantly.

Can these shoes handle technical hiking and scrambling?

The Oboz Sawtooth II Low performs adequately for light technical hiking and Class 2 scrambling but isn't designed for serious technical applications. The low-cut design provides less ankle support than mid or high-cut boots, making them best suited for well-maintained trails and moderate terrain. The outsole provides good traction on dry rock but struggles with wet surfaces and steep, loose terrain. For regular technical hiking or scrambling, consider the mid-cut version for additional ankle support or look at more technical-specific footwear. However, for the vast majority of hiking applications including day hikes, light backpacking, and moderate terrain navigation, these shoes excel and provide the versatility most hikers need.

Are replacement insoles available for long-term use?

Yes, Oboz sells replacement O FIT insoles separately, which is a significant advantage for long-term users of the Sawtooth II Low. The proprietary insoles are specifically molded for each shoe model, ensuring proper fit and support characteristics when replacements are needed. This availability extends the useful life of the shoes significantly since the insole often shows wear before the shoe structure itself needs replacement. The replacement insoles cost approximately $30-40 and maintain the same arch support and comfort characteristics as the originals. This serviceability aspect adds value to the initial investment and supports the environmental benefits of extending shoe lifespan rather than premature replacement due to insole degradation.

Conclusion

After extensive testing across diverse trail conditions and thorough analysis of user feedback, the Oboz Sawtooth II Low emerges as a compelling choice for serious day hikers and light backpackers. These shoes excel in the crucial areas of comfort, durability, and all-day support that matter most for extended trail adventures.

The standout feature remains the O FIT insole system, which provides exceptional arch support that maintains its characteristics through hundreds of miles of use. This level of foot support, combined with the generous toe box and secure heel fit, creates a comfort profile that few competitors match. The immediate wearability without break-in requirements makes these shoes particularly appealing for hikers who need reliable performance from day one.

However, the Oboz Sawtooth II Low isn't perfect for every application. The outsole design struggles with mud retention and wet rock traction, limiting performance in challenging conditions. The weight penalty compared to ultralight alternatives may concern gram-counting hikers, and the premium price point requires careful consideration of hiking frequency and requirements.

Final Recommendation

The Oboz Sawtooth II Low earns my strong recommendation for hikers who prioritize long-term comfort and durability over weight savings or budget constraints. These shoes represent an excellent investment for regular trail users who appreciate superior arch support and reliable performance across varied terrain conditions.

For hikers considering their first serious hiking shoe purchase or those upgrading from entry-level footwear, the Sawtooth II Low provides a significant step up in comfort and construction quality. The environmental commitment through tree planting programs adds ethical value to the practical benefits, making these shoes a responsible choice for environmentally conscious outdoor enthusiasts.

The decision ultimately depends on your hiking priorities and budget. If you value immediate comfort, exceptional support, and long-term durability above weight savings, the Oboz Sawtooth II Low delivers outstanding value. For occasional hikers or those prioritizing minimal weight, consider lighter alternatives, but recognize the comfort and support trade-offs involved.

My personal experience confirms that these shoes excel at their intended purpose: providing reliable, comfortable performance for the hiking adventures that define our connection to the outdoors. Whether exploring national park trails or discovering local hiking gems, the Sawtooth II Low proves itself a worthy companion for the miles ahead.

Start Your Trail Adventure with Oboz Sawtooth II Low
